instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used to predict concentrations of various water quality parameters (WQPs) in urban rivers?
Output: The related study used remote sensing spectrum to predict concentrations of various water quality parameters (WQPs) in urban rivers.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to predict concentrations of various water quality parameters (WQPs) in urban rivers?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods used to predict concentrations of various water quality parameters (WQPs) in urban rivers included progressively decreasing deep neural network (pDNN), multimodal deep learning (MDL), color space, spherical, and cosine transformation, genetic algorithm with back propagation, and semi-analytical methods.

instruction: What metric was chosen to predict concentrations of various water quality parameters (WQPs) in urban rivers, and how well did it perform?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the proposed SMPE-GCN method is the root of mean squared error (RMSE), mean absolute percent error (MAPE), and coefficient of determination (R2). The experimental results showed that the proposed method achieved better performance compared to state-of-the-art baseline models in terms of RMSE, MAPE, and R2. The resulting MAPE ranges from 7.16% to 10.96% and R2 ranges from 0.80 to 0.94 for all water quality parameters (WQPs). This indicates that the proposed method performed well in accurately predicting the concentrations of WQPs using UAV hyperspectral reflectance data.

instruction: What is the significance of integrating a graph convolution network (GCN), gravity model variant, and dual feedback machine in the development of the SMPE-GCN model for predicting WQPs using UAV remote sensing data?
Output:
The significance of integrating a graph convolution network (GCN), gravity model variant, and dual feedback machine in the development of the SMPE-GCN model for predicting water quality parameters (WQPs) using UAV remote sensing data is that it allows for a more accurate and efficient calculation of WQP concentrations on a large scale.

The graph convolution network (GCN) is a deep learning-based method that is used to analyze and process the UAV hyperspectral reflectance data. By incorporating GCN into the SMPE-GCN model, it enables the model to effectively capture the spatial distribution patterns of the WQPs, which is crucial for understanding the variation in water quality.

The gravity model variant is another component of the SMPE-GCN model that helps in quantifying the potential pollution sources. It takes into account the parametric probability analysis and spatial distribution pattern analysis, allowing the model to trace and identify the sources of pollution in real time. This is important for environmental protection departments to take immediate action and mitigate the pollution.

The dual feedback machine in the SMPE-GCN model provides a feedback loop that improves the accuracy of the predictions. It involves iterative processes of data acquisition, feature engineering, data conversion, and data modeling.

instruction: Can the proposed SMPE-GCN model using UAV remote sensing data be considered as a superior method compared to traditional approaches for real-time quantitative water quality monitoring in urban rivers?
Output:
Yes, the proposed SMPE-GCN model using UAV remote sensing data can be considered as a superior method compared to traditional approaches for real-time quantitative water quality monitoring in urban rivers. The model integrates a deep learning-based method, graph convolution network (GCN), gravity model variant, and dual feedback machine to efficiently calculate concentrations of water quality parameters (WQPs) through UAV hyperspectral reflectance data on a large scale. 

The model has been trained on a real-world dataset and validated on an equal amount of testing dataset using three evaluation metrics: root of mean squared error (RMSE), mean absolute percent error (MAPE), and coefficient of determination (R2). The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model outperforms state-of-the-art baseline models in terms of RMSE, MAPE, and R2.

Furthermore, the proposed method is applicable for quantifying seven various WQPs, including phosphorus, nitrogen, chemical oxygen demand (COD), biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), chlorophyll a (Chl-a), total suspended solids (TSS), and turbidity.
